metadata.titleEn: The china-russia crude oil pipeline freezing and thawing and waterlogging liability based attribute data set (2019)
metadata.description: The china-russia crude oil pipeline along the water system, in some low-lying section, surface runoff crossing pipelines, easy to form the waterlogging erosion and surface water, abundant water supplies in some extents, prone to frozen heaving and heat surface runoff of water erosion caused the pipe deformation, affect the operation safety.Using data collection, remote sensing (June 2019), a field investigation (September 2019) to obtain the elevation along pipeline, the types of frozen soil, topography, soil, vegetation, based attribute data, pipeline buried depth and so on, also received the type of water erosion and runoff, latitude and longitude, the information such as length, width, area, by freezing and thawing and waterlogging is used evaluation, calculate the freeze-thaw and waterlogging along pipeline liability probability.This data set is the pipe freezing and thawing and waterlogging liability results of quantitative evaluation can provide basic data for pipeline stability evaluation.
metadata.instructions: Excel statistical tables, fields including latitude and longitude, elevation, frozen soil type, topography, soil, vegetation, and pipeline buried depth, water type, scope, etc.

background: The China–Russia crude oil pipeline (CRCOP) begins in Skovorodino, Russia, enters China in Xing’an, Mohe County, and terminates in Daqing, Heilongjiang Province. The pipeline traverses a total of 441 km over permafrost regions. Along the pipeline, due to the complex topography, high forest coverage, and dense vegetation, stream flows have developed owing to the large amounts of precipitation and fertile soil in these regions. Due to interactions between the pipeline and the underlying permafrost, the thermal condition of the foundation soil varies markedly in different terrains. Freeze–thaw processes increase the maximum thawing depth under the pipe, which results in significant settlement. The permafrost in eastern China is known as Xing’an-Baikal permafrost. At altitudes lower than 800 m along the pipeline, the permafrost is thermally unstable and ecologically sensitive to climate change. With the development of global warming and anthropogenic activities, permafrost in eastern China has been degraded 50–150 km northward of the Xing’anling Mountains over the past 50 years. Previous literature regarding buried pipes in permafrost regions mainly focused on the thermal effects, calculations, and forecasts of freeze–thaw processes in the context of oil transportation at above-freezing temperatures. In addition to theoretical analyses and calculations, field monitoring is a necessary method to reveal the mechanisms of pipe deformation and interactions between pipes and permafrost. Frost heave and thaw settlement in permafrost regions along a pipeline are related to the ice content, the amount of moisture in the active layer, and the quantity of ground surface water. Apart from frost heave and thaw settlement, water erosion from surface flow is the main cause of damage to pipe embankments, which can aggravate pipe settlement.
research objective: Therefore, it is necessary to acquire the spatial distribution of water features along the CRCOP, and analyze the various hazard probabilities and their controlling factors. In this paper, ponds and erosive damage sites along the CRCOP were found. The distribution of water bodies was extracted by the normalized difference water index (NDWI) from Landsat 8 images. The main influential factors were selected, and their attributes were considered in a logistic regression model that was used to regress the weight of each factor and calculate the probability of freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage to the CRCOP. The results of this study may provide a scientific basis and reference for the hazard treatment and operation management of pipes in permafrost regions.
challenges: However, due to a lack of detailed data related to the basic geological and geophysical properties along the CRCOP, there has been little work on obtaining quantitative relationships, and providing forecasts of hazard occurrence along the route. Moreover, ponding and runoff erosion along the pipeline have not been considered in any assessment model to date.
methods: During our field survey, the position (latitude, longitude, and altitude), size (length and width), formation, and relation of the ponds relative to the pipe embankment were measured. The buried depths of the pipe, landform types, vegetation types, soil types, and ice content were collected from a 400 km length along the pipeline before the pipe was encased in pavement. The data were collected every 2 km during the survey; this spacing was determined by considering the feasibility and cost of designing and constructing the pipeline. Ponds on both sides of the pipeline in the range of 300 m were identified and extracted from the NDWI. After the regression, the weight of each influential factor was obtained from the coefficient of the independent variable(s). The probabilities of freeze–thaw hazards and water erosion were then calculated with the derived logistic regression model.
dataset: The study region is a 400 km length along the CRCOP in permafrost regions of northeastern China. The field survey, which was conducted in August, 2018, identified 102 pond sites and 223 water erosion sites next to the pipeline. The normalized difference water index (NDWI) was calculated based on Landsat 8 images from May, 2018. The images were provided by the geospatial data cloud site, which is part of the Computer Network Information Center, Chinese Academy of Sciences. From the field survey, 102 pond sites and 223 water erosion sites were identified along a 400 km long stretch of the CRCOP. From the results of the remote sensing image interpretation, 264 water bodies within 300 m either side of the pipeline were found, and most of them had an area larger than 500 m².
findings: The sections of pipe with the highest risks of freeze–thaw and erosive damage accounted for 2.4% and 6.7%, respectively, of the pipeline. The amount pipeline with a high risk (probability > 80%) of frost heave and thaw settlement accounted for 2.4%, or 11 km, of the total length, which was distributed in ice-rich permafrost regions. The pipeline with the highest risk (probability > 80%) of water erosion accounted for 6.7%, or 30 km, of the total length, which was located in valleys containing surface flows.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to assess the spatial distribution of water features along a pipeline in permafrost regions?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to assess the spatial distribution of water features along a pipeline in permafrost regions is the use of the normalized difference water index (NDWI) derived from Landsat 8 images. This method was utilized to identify and extract ponds and erosive damage sites along a 400 km length of the pipeline. The field survey, complemented by NDWI analysis, helped in capturing the position, size, and relation of water bodies relative to the pipeline.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in obtaining quantitative relationships for hazard forecasting along pipelines in permafrost areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in obtaining quantitative relationships for hazard forecasting along pipelines in permafrost areas is the lack of detailed data related to the basic geological and geophysical properties along the pipeline. This scarcity of data limits the ability to provide accurate forecasts of hazard occurrence, particularly concerning ponding and runoff erosion, which have not been fully considered in existing assessment models.

Feature Specification.Answer: high elevation, permafrost types, soil texture, vegetation, terrain features, pipeline burial depth, ponding and runoff erosion types, latitude, longitude, length, width, area

Feature Specification.Answer: field surveys, remote sensing, normalized difference water index (NDWI), Landsat 8 images, within 300 m of the pipeline

Definition.Question: What does 'logistic regression model' mean in the context of assessing freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage?
Definition.Answer: In this context, a 'logistic regression model' refers to a statistical method used to regress the weight of influential factors and calculate the probability of freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage to the pipeline. The model helps in quantifying the relationship between various factors and the occurrence of these hazards, providing a scientific basis for hazard treatment and operation management.

Definition.Question: What does 'field survey' entail when collecting data along a pipeline in permafrost regions?
Definition.Answer: A 'field survey' in this context involves collecting data on various attributes such as position (latitude, longitude, and altitude), size (length and width), and formation of ponds relative to the pipe embankment. It also includes gathering information on buried depths of the pipe, landform types, vegetation types, soil types, and ice content along a specific length of the pipeline. This data is crucial for understanding the interaction between the pipeline and its environment and assessing the risk of hazards.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques used in remote sensing image interpretation compare to those employed in field surveys for assessing freeze-thaw hazards along pipeline routes?
Comparison.Answer: Remote sensing image interpretation, such as using the normalized difference water index (NDWI) from Landsat 8 images, allows for the identification of water bodies along the pipeline over a large area. In contrast, field surveys involve direct measurements of geographic features like ponds and erosive sites, collecting detailed data on pond positions, sizes, and soil properties. Both methods provide valuable insights, with remote sensing offering a broader overview and field surveys providing more in-depth data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methods for identifying water erosion sites differ from those used to locate ponds along a pipeline, and what are the implications for data accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: Identifying water erosion sites often involves field surveys that measure erosive damage near the pipeline, focusing on physical signs of erosion. Locating ponds, however, combines field surveys with remote sensing techniques like NDWI to detect water bodies. The dual approach for ponds may offer greater accuracy in their identification, as it cross-verifies remote sensing results with ground-truth data, whereas water erosion site identification relies more heavily on direct observation, potentially limiting the scope of detection.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in collecting detailed geological and geophysical data along the pipeline, and how might these challenges affect the ability to establish quantitative relationships for hazard forecasting?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include a lack of detailed data related to the basic geological and geophysical properties along the pipeline. This limitation affects the ability to establish quantitative relationships necessary for forecasting hazards. Without this detailed data, it is difficult to accurately model and predict the occurrence of hazards, such as freeze-thaw and erosive damage, along the pipeline route.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in collecting detailed geological and geophysical data along the CRCOP, especially in permafrost regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in collecting detailed geological and geophysical data along the CRCOP are primarily due to the complex topography, high forest coverage, dense vegetation, and the requirement of field monitoring to understand pipe deformation and interactions with permafrost. Additionally, the lack of detailed data limits the ability to obtain quantitative relationships and forecasts of hazard occurrences along the pipeline.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to acquire spatial distribution data of water features along the CRCOP for assessing hazard probabilities?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Acquiring the spatial distribution of water features along the CRCOP is necessary because the ponds and erosive damage sites influence the probabilities of freeze-thaw hazards and erosive damage. Understanding the distribution of water bodies, which are extracted using the normalized difference water index (NDWI), helps in analyzing the controlling factors and calculating the probability of hazards, thus providing a scientific basis for pipeline hazard treatment and operation management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in integrating ponding and runoff erosion data into assessment models for the CRCOP?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in integrating ponding and runoff erosion data into assessment models for the CRCOP arises from the lack of detailed data related to the basic geological and geophysical properties along the pipeline. This deficiency hampers the development of quantitative relationships and the provision of forecasts for hazard occurrences, as ponding and runoff erosion have not been considered in previous assessment models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating remote sensing data such as the normalized difference water index (NDWI) with field survey data on the evaluation of freeze–thaw hazards along crude oil pipelines?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data like NDWI with field survey data can enhance the spatial distribution analysis of water features and improve the accuracy of hazard probability assessments, providing a more comprehensive understanding of freeze–thaw hazards along crude oil pipelines.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the absence of detailed geological and geophysical data affect the quantitative analysis and modeling of hazard occurrence along pipeline routes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The absence of detailed geological and geophysical data can hinder the development of accurate quantitative models, making it challenging to predict hazard occurrences and assess the risks posed by freeze–thaw cycles and water erosion along pipeline routes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of solely relying on logistic regression models for calculating freeze–thaw hazard probabilities in permafrost regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying solely on logistic regression models could lead to oversimplifications, as it may not account for all influencing factors or interactions between variables. This could result in less precise hazard probability estimations, potentially affecting pipeline stability assessments.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to collect data on the spatial distribution of water features along the China–Russia crude oil pipeline?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is essential to collect data on the spatial distribution of water features to analyze hazard probabilities and their controlling factors, which can provide a scientific basis and reference for hazard treatment and operation management of pipes in permafrost regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of using the normalized difference water index (NDWI) and logistic regression model in the assessment of freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage along pipelines?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of using the NDWI and logistic regression model is to extract the distribution of water bodies and calculate the probabilities of freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage, thereby providing a quantitative evaluation of potential risks along the pipeline.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing techniques be utilized to assess water erosion and freeze-thaw hazards along a pipeline route in permafrost regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Remote sensing techniques, such as the extraction of water bodies using the normalized difference water index (NDWI) from Landsat 8 images, can be utilized. The NDWI helps identify ponds and erosive damage sites. The spatial distribution of these water features is then analyzed to assess hazard probabilities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for conducting a field survey to collect geological and hydrological data along a crude oil pipeline in permafrost regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The field survey involves measuring the position (latitude, longitude, and altitude), size (length and width), formation, and relation of water features to the pipeline. Data on buried depths, landform types, vegetation types, soil types, and ice content are collected. This is done systematically, every 2 km, considering feasibility and cost, over a specified length along the pipeline.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can logistic regression models be applied to evaluate the risk of pipeline deformation due to environmental factors in permafrost regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Logistic regression models can be applied by selecting influential factors related to environmental risks, such as soil type and moisture content. The attributes of these factors are included in the model to regress their weights. The resulting probabilities of freeze-thaw hazards and water erosion are calculated to evaluate the risk of pipeline deformation.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the acquisition of accurate data on the spatial distribution of water features along pipelines in permafrost regions?
Enablement.Answer: The spatial distribution of water features along pipelines can be acquired using the normalized difference water index (NDWI) from Landsat 8 images. Field surveys are also conducted to identify pond and erosion sites, measuring their position, size, and relation to the pipe embankment.

Enablement.Question: Which conditions and resources facilitate the accurate assessment of freeze–thaw hazard probabilities in pipeline regions?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate assessments of freeze–thaw hazard probabilities are facilitated by the collection of detailed data on the position, size, formation, and relation of ponds relative to the pipe embankment, as well as the buried depth of the pipe, landform types, vegetation types, soil types, and ice content. A logistic regression model is then used to analyze these factors.

Enablement.Question: How does remote sensing technology enable the identification and extraction of water bodies near pipelines in challenging terrains?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing technology, specifically the use of Landsat 8 images and the calculation of the normalized difference water index (NDWI), enables the identification and extraction of water bodies within 300 m on either side of the pipeline, even in challenging terrains.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in acquiring detailed geological and geophysical property data along a pipeline in permafrost regions?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the lack of detailed data related to the basic geological and geophysical properties along the CRCOP, it has been challenging to obtain quantitative relationships and provide forecasts of hazard occurrence along the route.

Expectation.Question: What complicates the process of predicting freeze-thaw hazards and water erosion along a pipeline?
Expectation.Answer: The prediction of freeze-thaw hazards and water erosion is complicated by the absence of ponding and runoff erosion considerations in any current assessment model, as well as the lack of detailed geological and geophysical data.

Expectation.Question: Why is remote sensing, such as using the normalized difference water index (NDWI), used in identifying water features near pipelines?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing is used because it allows for the extraction of the spatial distribution of water bodies, such as ponds and erosive damage sites, along the pipeline, which is necessary for analyzing hazard probabilities and their controlling factors.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you believe data collection methods like remote sensing and field surveys are in capturing the diverse environmental interactions affecting pipelines in permafrost regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing, such as using the normalized difference water index from satellite images, and field surveys, which gather detailed on-site data, are effective in capturing environmental interactions like water erosion and freeze-thaw effects on pipelines. These methods provide spatial distribution and influential factors, although a lack of comprehensive geological and geophysical data can limit the precision of hazard probability assessments.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the most significant challenges in integrating field survey data with remote sensing data for modeling pipeline hazards in permafrost regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The most significant challenges include ensuring consistency between data from different sources, such as aligning spatial and temporal resolutions, and adequately representing the complexity of interactions between pipelines and their environments. Additionally, limited detailed geological and geophysical data may hinder the ability to establish quantitative relationships in hazard modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can effectively capture the spatial distribution of water features along a pipeline in permafrost regions.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods effectively capture the spatial distribution of water features by using a combination of field surveys and remote sensing techniques. In the field survey, the position, size, and type of water features are measured. Remote sensing, such as the normalized difference water index (NDWI) from satellite images, is used to extract the distribution of water bodies.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when trying to quantify the relationship between geological properties and hazard probabilities along a pipeline.
Assertion.Answer: One of the challenges in quantifying the relationship between geological properties and hazard probabilities is the lack of detailed data for the basic geological and geophysical properties along the pipeline. This makes it difficult to establish quantitative relationships and forecast hazard occurrences. Additionally, factors like ponding and runoff erosion have not been fully integrated into existing assessment models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze data collection techniques used to assess freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage probabilities along pipeline routes in permafrost regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection techniques for assessing freeze–thaw hazards and erosive damage probabilities along pipeline routes include field surveys to measure pond positions, sizes, and their relation to the pipeline. Additionally, the NDWI derived from Landsat 8 images is used to extract water bodies, with logistic regression models applied to analyze hazards based on influential factors collected during field surveys.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify challenges in collecting quantitative relationships for hazard forecasts along pipelines in permafrost regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting quantitative relationships for hazard forecasts along pipelines include the lack of detailed data on basic geological and geophysical properties, and the absence of ponding and runoff erosion considerations in current assessment models. These challenges hinder the ability to provide accurate forecasts of hazard occurrence.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose strategies for expanding datasets related to ponding and water erosion impacts on pipeline stability in permafrost areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for expanding datasets related to ponding and water erosion impacts on pipeline stability could involve increasing the frequency and density of field survey data collection points, integrating additional remote sensing data sources, and incorporating more detailed geological and hydrological data to enhance the understanding of water dynamics and their effects on pipeline stability.
